author: @veenak108
text: Question: When we try to change a global variable within a local space the new variable gets created (As in your video at time 5:00). Is this case true only for immutable objects? Because if I try to change a mutable global object (without declaring it as global) in a function it doesn't create a new object. Please see the example below: Both print statements will output a[1] as 0. a = [1, 2, 3] def fun():     a[1] = 0      print(a) fun() print(a)    My understanding here is "A new local object is created if we try to assign a value to a immutable global objects inside a function and if we do the same with a mutable object there isn't a  new object created, rather the assignment changes the same global object." Is my understanding correct ?

author: @sebek0311
text: @Corey Schafer - You forgot about one of the most crucial thing in this topic. How to pass values from one function to the other. You only described how to change the value of the global variable outside the function, but not even a single world about how to make other functions "understand each other..." :( using global: def func1():     global a, b     a = 8     b = 9   def func2(x, y):     func1() # I have not seen this here anywhere and I think that is the main reason why you wanna learn that topic...     z = x + y + a + b     return z   a = func2(4, 6) print(a)  using enclosing scope:  def func1():  a = 8   b = 9        def func2(x,y):       z = x + y + a + b       print(z)    func2(9,22)   func1()

author: @sonumpsah1
text: @corey, What a great video!!! Just adding support for python 2.X The nonlocal keyword does not exist in python 2.X, so here is the way around. (choose any one from those two) def outer():     x= {'x': 'outer x'}     def inner():         x['x']= 'inner x'         print x['x']     outer()     print x['x']  def outer():     outer.x= 'outer x'     def inner():         outer.x= 'inner x'         print outer.x     outer()     print outer.x  Output: inner x inner x

author: @vasanthkumar5269
text: A small but an important point is missed. Unlike other languages, a variable that is defined in a loop lives in its enclosing scope, not only inside the loop.   def a_func():     x = 5     while(x > 0):         i = 10         x -= 1     print(i)  a_func()  o/p: 10
